hero.title: WeWork — 2012 Pitch Deck
hero.subtitle: A high-variance model examined using the same fixed report structure.

cards.title: Narrative strength
cards.summary: Brand and community framing is differentiated and compelling.

cards.title: Fixed-cost exposure
cards.summary: Long-duration liabilities create significant macro and occupancy risk.

cards.title: Scaling opacity
cards.summary: Rapid expansion can mask weak unit economics at location level.

lists.title: Core strengths
items: Potential premium pricing in select hubs

personas.name: Brand Optimist
personas.summary: Believes customer love can support premium occupancy outcomes.

personas.name: Balance-Sheet Skeptic
personas.summary: Focuses on downside from fixed liabilities and demand shocks.

personas.name: Execution Moderate
personas.summary: Wants slower, gated expansion with strict unit thresholds.

rounds.title: Round 1 — Initial IC pass
rounds.summary: Narrative acknowledged, but core underwriting questions remain unresolved.

rounds.title: Round 2 — Downside simulation
rounds.summary: Stress tests indicate fragile outcomes under mild occupancy compression.

rounds.title: Round 3 — Decision gate
rounds.summary: Committee declines at current terms pending stronger site-level proof.
points: Revisit if economics become demonstrably resilient

stage_4.summary: Compelling storytelling is outweighed by fixed-cost and scaling risk at this stage.
insights: Demand narrative alone is insufficient for underwriting
Downside protection is weak without flexible cost structure
questions: What occupancy threshold preserves contribution margin?
How resilient is churn in downturn conditions?
What objective signals trigger expansion pauses?
plans: Model downside occupancy and pricing scenarios
